location_listing.description:
The Bhagat Singh Museum, located in Khatkar Kalan, Punjab, India, pays homage to the legendary freedom fighter, Shaheed Bhagat Singh, one of the most influential revolutionaries of the Indian independence movement. The museum's reception area serves as the gateway for visitors to embark on a historical journey, offering a glimpse into the life and times of Bhagat Singh and his contributions to India's struggle for freedom.

Upon entering the reception, visitors are greeted with an ambiance that resonates with the spirit of patriotism and sacrifice. The area is adorned with portraits of Bhagat Singh and other freedom fighters, alongside informative plaques that provide a brief overview of their heroic deeds and the significance of their struggle. The reception desk is staffed by knowledgeable personnel who guide visitors through the museum's exhibits, which include personal belongings of Bhagat Singh, letters, and documents related to the freedom movement, as well as a collection of books and literature that influenced his thoughts and actions.

The "Echoes of Jallianwala: April 13, 1919" gallery in the Bhagat Singh Museum solemnly commemorates the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, a pivotal moment in India's struggle for independence. On that day, British forces brutally fired on unarmed civilians in Amritsar, causing significant loss of life and marking a turning point in public sentiment towards British rule. This gallery presents a concise yet powerful portrayal through photographs, documents, and survivor accounts, capturing the tragedy's impact and its role in galvanizing the Indian freedom movement. Visitors are invited to reflect on the sacrifice and resilience that shaped the nation's history, ensuring the memory of those lost continues to inspire future generations.

The "Journey of a Revolutionary: Bhagat Singh 1907-1931" gallery encapsulates the life and legacy of Shaheed Bhagat Singh, one of India's most iconic freedom fighters. Born in 1907, Bhagat Singh grew up in a period of intense nationalistic fervor, which shaped his revolutionary ideals. This gallery takes visitors through a chronological journey of Bhagat Singh's life, highlighting key moments from his birth in Punjab, to his involvement in the Indian freedom movement, and his ultimate sacrifice in 1931.

Through a collection of photographs, personal letters, artifacts, and informative panels, the gallery portrays Bhagat Singh's evolution from a young patriot to a symbol of resistance against British rule. Key milestones include his participation in the Non-Cooperation Movement, the dramatic protest against the Simon Commission, the Lahore Conspiracy Case, and his hunger strike for equal rights for Indian prisoners.

The gallery culminates with Bhagat Singh's execution on March 23, 1931, leaving behind a legacy that continues to inspire generations. Visitors leave with a deeper understanding of Bhagat Singh's contribution to India's freedom struggle and his enduring significance in the nation's history.
location_listing.location_name: The Journey of a Revolutionary: Bhagat Singh 1907-1931

location_listing.description:
The "Echoes of Inquilab: The Cry of Freedom" gallery at the Bhagat Singh Museum captures the essence and impact of the iconic slogan "Inquilab Zindabad" (Long Live the Revolution), which became synonymous with India's struggle for independence. Coined and popularized by freedom fighters like Bhagat Singh, this powerful phrase ignited the hearts of millions, encouraging them to stand against colonial rule.

This gallery showcases the origins, spread, and significance of "Inquilab Zindabad" through a vivid collection of artifacts, photographs, and documents. Visitors can explore interactive displays that trace the slogan's journey from its inception, its adoption by various freedom movements across India, to its enduring legacy in the collective memory of the nation.

Featuring multimedia presentations that bring historical speeches and rallies to life, the gallery offers an immersive experience of the revolutionary fervor that "Inquilab Zindabad" inspired. It serves as a testament to the spirit of resistance and unity among Indians in their fight for sovereignty and self-determination.

"Echoes of Inquilab: The Cry of Freedom" not only commemorates a pivotal moment in India's history but also celebrates the enduring power of words to inspire change and mobilize a nation towards its quest for freedom.
location_listing.location_name: Echoes of Inquilab: The Cry of Freedom

location_listing.description:
The "Relics of Revolution: Bhagat Singh's Legacy" gallery in the Bhagat Singh Museum offers a profound insight into the life of one of India's most revered freedom fighters. This gallery is meticulously curated to display an array of artifacts and personal belongings that belonged to Bhagat Singh, each telling a story of courage, intellect, and sacrifice.

Visitors can closely examine Bhagat Singh's handwritten notes, letters exchanged with fellow revolutionaries and family, as well as the books that influenced his revolutionary ideologies. The gallery also houses his personal items like clothing, the pen used for writing his last letter, and more, offering a tangible connection to the legend himself.

Enhanced with graphic panels that provide detailed narratives of the items on display, the gallery invites visitors to delve deeper into Bhagat Singh's life. Touch kiosks placed strategically throughout the space allow for an interactive exploration, enabling visitors to engage with multimedia presentations on Bhagat Singh's contributions to India's freedom struggle, his philosophies, and his enduring legacy.

"Relics of Revolution: Bhagat Singh's Legacy" stands as a powerful reminder of the sacrifices made for India's independence, inspiring visitors to reflect on the values of freedom, justice, and the indomitable spirit of resistance.
location_listing.location_name: Relics of Revolution: Bhagat Singh's Legacy

location_listing.description:
Revolution is an inalienable right of mankind. Freedom is an imperishable birthright of all.’
These revolutionary ideas propounded by Shaheed Bhagat Singh (27 September 1907 - 23 March 1931) spurred a wave of nationalism during India’s freedom struggle. A young, energatic & fearless patriot, Bhagat Singh’s immutable childhood dream of a free India propelled him to stand strongly for India’s Independence. It showed to the world, the intensity of a charismatic leader, a potent and powerful idea and an empowered youth that propelled India’s freedom movement. Bhagat Singh was a voracious reader and a prolific writer. 
In a short spam of life, Bhagat Singh’s valour, vibranery and vision shook and shatted the minds of prominent Indian leaders, providing them with a parallel perspective to fight for India’s freedom. 
On the museum journey, witness the life story of one of India’s greatest freedom fighters and feel how the young patriot left an indelible and immutable impact on the history of India as well as the world.

Art Installation in the center with suspended “Inqilab Zindabad” ​
rotating in several languages. ​The central art installation at the museum features the iconic slogan "Inqilab Zindabad" (Long Live the Revolution) suspended in mid-air, creating a dynamic and captivating display. This powerful phrase, synonymous with the Indian freedom movement and Bhagat Singh's revolutionary zeal, rotates gracefully, revealing its message in several languages. This multilingual presentation not only celebrates the universal appeal of the quest for freedom and justice but also pays homage to Bhagat Singh's impact across diverse cultures and communities.

The installation's design ingeniously combines aesthetic appeal with historical significance, allowing visitors to engage with the essence of the freedom struggle in a profoundly interactive manner. As the slogan rotates, it casts shadows and reflections, symbolizing the far-reaching influence of Bhagat Singh's ideals and the enduring relevance of the fight for independence. This central piece serves as a reminder of the unity and diversity within the struggle for freedom, encouraging reflection on the collective aspirations and sacrifices that shaped India's history.

Sardar Bhagat Singh was born at 9 AM on September 28, 1907, into a Punjabi family in village Banga, Lyallpur, now Faislabad in Pakistan. Most members of his family were nationalists. Arjan Singh, the grandfather of Bhagat Singh, was a landlord and follower of Swami Dayanand Saraswati, who established the Arya Samaj, a social reform movement to remove inequities in society. A member of the Arya Samaj who 
promoted non-violent means, Arjan Singh played a significant role in diffusing the idea of Swaraj in Punjab. Bhagat Singh’s grandmother, Sardarni Jai Kaur, was also an ardent Arya Samaji who courageously supported Arjan Singh during India’s freedom struggle. Bhagat Singh often mentioned his grandmother in his writings as the source of his inspiration and dedication.
Bhagat Singh’s grandparents had three sons. Kishan Singh, Bhagat Singh’s father, was an active member of the Ghadar Party, who introduced to his son, the political ideology of socialism which found expression in his writings. Kishan Singh also instilled a passion for independence in Bhagat Singh. Bhagat Singh’s mother, Vidyawati Devi, was the source of his tenacity and determination. She did not let her 
son’s early demise dim the patriotism with which the Singh household countered colonisation. Her sacrifice and teachings made Bhagat Singh immortal in world history

An immersive room with Audio of Bhagat Singh’s mother’s speech, ​
who is represented through a holographic figure with a background ​
of their ancestral home fabrications.

The Ghadar Party was founded on 1 November 1913 in San Francisco, California (USA). Its objective was to impart ideas of nationalism to the Indian diaspora of youth and immigrants. The purpose was crystal clear: to tell the world that the British were not benevolent, but pilots of despotic rule. The movement appealed for unity among the Indian people; to fight against the British rule. The Ghadar Party diffused revolutionary ideology through arms and ideas, with an uncompromising dream of a sovereign republican India. 
Members of the Ghadar Party, including Sohan Singh Bhakna, Visakha Singh Dadeher, Jawala SinghThathia, Kartar Singh Sarabha, Lala Hardyal, Barakatullah Kahn & Tarak Nath Das strengthened their objectives with unwavering commitment. In 1914, Lala Hardayal, a revolutionary and profound scholar wrote: ‘The time for prayer and petition has gone, it is now time for the swords to speak.’ The Ghadarites are known for their struggle and sacrifices.

On 23 May 1914, the Japanese steamship Komagata Maru  reached Canada with 376 Indian immigrants onboard. However, passengers were denied entry as the Canadian Government, hostile to non-White immigration, had amended the Immigration Act (1910), Immigrants had to possess $200, eight times the amount mandated for the White Immigrants and had to show a continuous journey from their country of citizenship. The Canadian Government considered Indian immigrants as subjected of the British Empire rather than citizens.  
In a deadlock, legal proceedings against these discriminatory laws initiated by Indians in Vancouver continued for two months. The Canadian port authorities rationed supplies of food and water to the passengers. Subsequently, only 24 passengers were permitted into Canada. The rest returned to a colonised homeland. The Komagata Maru reached Calcutta (present Kolkata) on 27 September 1914. On 29 September 1914, the ship reached the Budge Ghat, 27 Kilometer from Calcutta. A scuffle broken out with 321 passangers on the ship. The police used gunfire & 22 passengers died. 
The Komagata Maru incident, involving violation of human rights and arbitrary detention of passengers, created outrage among the Indians and intensified freedom struggle in India.

The Immersive Show of the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, which had a powerful and heartening impact on the young Bhagat Singh and became a cause behind the emergence of a great revolutionary like him. This installation is visualized to represent the theme of the Jallianwala Bagh tragedy, which is achieved by projection mapping on the wall. The well of Jallianwala Bagh is recreated in the center, and the room is complemented by various related elements with the help of scenography.

The Kakori train action is a significant event that reflects the determination and courage of the freedom fighters. 
 On August 9, 1925, leaders of Hindustan Republican Association (HRA) Ram Prasad Bismil, Rajendra Lahiri, Roshan Singh and Ashfaqullah Khan sought to free the money bags, taxes paid by the Indians, being transferred to the British treasury on a train travelling from Shahjahanpur to Lucknow. At Kakori station, near Lucknow, the nationalists overpowered the guard and escaped to Lucknow with the bags.
This daring incident sent shockwaves within the colonial government and cemented the narrative that fierce Indian patriots were willing to sacrifice their lives for the nation. Following an intense manhunt, they were captured. Rajendra Lahiri was hanged on December 17, 1927 and others were hanged two days later. The incident successfully garnered public attention on the young martyrs’ mission for a free India.

The Indian Statutory Commission led by Sir John Simon, was formed by the British in 1927 to review the progress of constitutional reforms in India under the colonial rule. When Indian leaders realised that the panel did not include any Indian representative, an insulting gesture by the British administration, they demonstrated their rejection of the Simon Commission through strong protests, marches and speeches. 
The uprising against the Commission, primarily led by Lala Lajpat Rai in the Punjab region, led Bhagat Singh and his associates to join the cause without hesitation. Chants of 'Simon Go Back' led by Lala Lajpat Rai made him a direct target during the brutal lathi charge and arrests by the British. Lalaji's death on November 17, 1928 due to serious injuries sustained from the lathi charge became a catalyst for Bhagat Singh and other co-patriots to continue the movement for freedom.

1.   The Delhi Assembly Bombing of 1929 was a significant event in India's Independence movement. On April 8, 1929, two representatives of the HSRA, Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt, entered the Delhi Assembly and hurled two bombs at the seats occupied by government officials during the session preceding the passage of the Public Safety Bill and the Trade Disputes Bill.
2.   Amid the chaos of deafening sound and thick smoke, the benches shattered into pieces as people rushed out. Except for some minor injuries, however, there were no casualties. Some members of Parliament such as Pt. Madan Mohan Malviya, Pt. Motilal Nehru, Shri Vallabh Bhai Patel and Muhammad Ali Jinnah remained unmoved as they had complete confidence in Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt.
3.Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt’s entrance into the Assembly remains a mystery although they were known to have the area some days prior to the explosion. One of them had a fully loaded gun which he laid out on the table. Both of them shouted the slogan ‘Inquilab Zindabad!’. They did not try to escape.
4. Once the smoke cleared, Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt willingly courted arrest. Police Inspectors Terry and Johnson took the duo to the Chandni Chowk police station. Enroute, they distributed large red lettered leaflets with the words, ‘The Hindustan Socialist Republican Army' along with the slogan ‘It takes a loud voice to make the deaf hear.’ The incident drew international attention for India’s freedom struggle. 
5. The Delhi Assembly Bombing highlighted Indians’ growing frustration over colonial rule, and sparked widespread protests across the country. Senior leaders reposed their faith on Bhagat Singh and his associates.

This immersive experience transports visitors back to April 8, 1929, reenacting the historic Delhi Assembly bombing orchestrated by Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt. Within a specially designed closed room, spectators are given a bird's-eye view of the meticulously recreated scene of the Delhi Assembly. The exhibit captures the moment Bhagat Singh and Dutt threw non-lethal bombs onto the Assembly floor, not to harm but to "make the deaf hear" their demand for freedom and protest against repressive laws. Authentic sound effects, visual projections, and narrations recount the duo's courageous act and their subsequent arrest, highlighting their unwavering commitment to the cause of independence. This powerful depiction offers a unique insight into a pivotal event, emphasizing the sacrifices made in the struggle for India's freedom.

Bhagat Singh was imprisoned during the trial in the Lahore Conspiracy Case. While in the jail, Bhagat Singh and his fellow revolutionaries went on the hunger strike to protest the inhumane treatment of political prisoners, and to assert their inalienable human rights. The hunger strike lasted for 116 days, during which British authorities attempted to force-feed them. The movement led by Bhagat Singh from within the jail was a powerful act of resistance against colonialism. It gained widespread attention and inspired many others to join India’s freedom struggle. Bhagat Singh’s patriotic zeal and martyrdom is remembered to this day.

Bhagat Singh, a prominent figure in the Indian independence movement, left behind several artefacts and personal belongings that are significant to his legacy. Some notable items include:His distinctive attire, often consisting of a cap and simple kurta, symbolizes his revolutionary spirit.Handwritten letters, essays, and pamphlets where he articulated his thoughts on nationalism, socialism, and justice.Images of Singh, both formal and candid, capturing his personality and commitment to the freedom struggle Correspondences with friends, family, and fellow revolutionaries that provide insight into his thoughts and relationships.A collection of books he read, which influenced his ideology, including works on socialism and revolutionary movements.The Execution Notice: Documents related to his trial and execution, a poignant reminder of his sacrifice.Many of these artefacts are preserved in museums dedicated to his memory, such as the Bhagat Singh Museum in Khatkar Kalan, Punjab. They serve as a powerful reminder of his contributions to the fight for India’s independence.

The martyrdom of Bhagat Singh is often symbolically represented through several powerful elements:A flame symbolizes his undying spirit and the revolutionary fire he ignited in the hearts of many.This Sikh symbol represents courage and the fight against oppression, embodying Singh's commitment to justice.Often depicted alongside him, the gun signifies his readiness to confront colonial rule and his belief in armed resistance for freedom.Broken chains represent liberation from oppression and the struggle for independence, reflecting Singh's fight against British colonialism.Images of young people rallying together often symbolize the youth movement he inspired, emphasizing his role as a leader for future generations.His powerful words, such as "Revolution is not only about taking up arms but also about changing minds," highlight his ideological legacy.These symbols collectively capture Bhagat Singh's legacy as a martyr who fought for India's independence and inspired countless others.

Bharat Singh, a significant figure in Indian history, is associated with various movements and cultural changes. While there might not be dedicated historic newspapers or journals exclusively about him, you can find references in several historical newspapers, journals, and archives that discuss the broader context of his time.Indian Newspapers: Look for publications like The Times of India, Hindustan Times, and regional newspapers from the period to find articles or editorials discussing his contributions.Historical Journals: Journals focusing on Indian history, such as the Indian Historical Review or Modern Asian Studies, may contain articles that reference his impact on society and politics.Archives: The National Archives of India and state archives may hold collections of documents, letters, and newspapers that provide insight into his life and work.Digital Resources: Websites like the Digital South Asia Library or the British Library’s India Office Records might have digitized newspapers and journals where he is mentioned.

Bhagat Singh, the prominent Indian revolutionary, left behind a wealth of writings and inscribed notes that reflect his thoughts on freedom, justice, and his vision for India. His notes often expressed a deep commitment to socialism and a critique of British colonial rule, as well as an exploration of his philosophical beliefs.Singh believed that true freedom could only be achieved through revolutionary action. His writings often highlighted the need for unity among the oppressed.He was influenced by socialist ideologies and believed in the need for a system that serves the working class, advocating for the redistribution of wealth.Singh grappled with the ethics of violence in revolutionary movements. He justified it as a necessary means to an end while also reflecting on its moral implications.Despite his revolutionary fervor, Singh's notes often emphasized human dignity and the importance of fighting for the rights of all individuals.He stressed the need for political education and consciousness among the masses, believing that awareness was key to mobilization.Singh's writings are considered not just historical documents but also profound philosophical reflections that continue to inspire movements for justice and equality.

1907: Bhagat Singh was born on September 27, 1907 in village Banga, Lyallpur District, Punjab Province (present-day Faisalabad, Punjab, Pakistan).
1911: Admitted to the district board primary school, in Banga. 
1917: Joined the DAV High School in Lahore.
1919: As a young boy, Bhagat Singh skipped school to visit the site of the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre and collected the bloodstained soil to honour the martyrs. 
1920: Participated in Mahatma Gandhi’s Non-Cooperation Movement and defied British colonialism by following Gandhi's directives of burning the government’s school books, and imported British clothing.
1921: Joined the National College in Lahore, where he took an interest in extracurricular activities.
1923: Passed the Intermediate Examination (F.A.). He ran away from home to Cownpore (present-day Kanpur) to avoid marriage.  
1924: Returned home in six months to evade an arrest warrant issued for his involvement in organising a langar during the Jaito Morcha in Banga village. Bhagat Singh then worked as the head teacher  at the National School of Shadipur, Aligarh. In Kanpur, he became a member of the Hindustan Republican Association (HRA), started by Sachindranath Sanyal. He also became a close associate of Chandra Shekhar Azad, the main organiser of the HRA. 
1926: Bhagat Singh founded the Naujawan Bharat Sabha, an organisation that aimed to encourage revolution against the British rule by provoking the working class. 
1927: Bhagat Singh was arrested on charges associated with the Kakori Case. He was accused of writing a politically charged article under the pseudonym ‘Vidrohi’. 
1928: Bhagat Singh primarily influenced the discussion for the change of name of the HRA to the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA) along with Sukhdev Thapar and Chandrashekhar Azad. He swore  to avenge Lala Lajpat Rai's death following a lathi charge by the police during a silent protest led by Chandrashekhar Azad against the Simon Commission. Bhagat Singh joined other revolutionaries to plot the assassination of James A. Scott, the Superintendent of Police who had ordered the lathi charge.  
1929: Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt hurled two bombs in Delhi’s Central Legislative Assembly. The explosives were a protest against the Public Safety Bill and the Trade Disputes Bill—new laws designed to curb citizens' civil liberties.
1930: The Hindustan Socialist Republican Association steadily declined since by 1930 the most of its leaders were either imprisoned or had been executed. 
1931: After the martyrdom of Chandrashekar Azad on February 27 1931, the HSRA lost most of its prominent leaders. 
1931: Bhagat Singh, Rajguru and Sukhdev were hanged to death on March 23 following the judgment in the Lahore Conspiracy Case.

Bhagat Singh, a prominent figure in the Indian independence movement, is celebrated for his bravery and commitment to the cause of freedom. His "Shaheedi Jyot" refers to the spirit of martyrdom he embodied, inspiring countless others in the struggle against British colonial rule.Bhagat Singh believed in the power of revolutionary action and the importance of social justice. His writings and activism focused on the plight of the oppressed and the need for radical change. He famously stated, "Revolution is not a bed of roses," highlighting the sacrifices required for liberation.His execution on March 23, 1931, at a young age solidified his legacy as a martyr for the nation. The "Shaheedi Jyot" symbolizes the enduring influence of his ideals and the continuing fight for justice and equality in India. His courage and dedication are commemorated annually, inspiring new generations to stand up for their rights and ideals.

The Shaheed-e-Azam Bhagat Singh Museum located in Khatkar Kalan, the village where he grew up, displays an array of memorabilia associated with his life, and death, including personal effects, photographs and pages from his personal diary. A copy ofthe judgement of the Lahore Conspiracy case sentencing him to death by hanging along with Kartar Singh Sarabha can be viewed here; as also an edition of the Bhagwad Gita with his name on it. It was presented to him by an employee off the Lahore Jail where he was lodged. A stained and crumpled old newspaper, announcing their hanging, has been preserved alongside remainscollected by Bhagat Singh's sister from the cremation site.The most poignant of them all however, is the pen that pronounced the death sentence on Punjab's greatest revolutionaries. A section of the display hall pays photographic tribute to the martyrs of the Kuka movement as well as those of the Gadar Party. The remaining walls are lined by pictures of the countless revolutionaries involved in the freedom movement. The grounds of the museum also house Bhagat Singh's father's granite-clad samadh; it is located to the left of the entrance gate. Less than a kilometer away in the village lies his ancestral house and can be accessed free of cost, too. Timings: 9am–4.45 pm (Tues-Sun) / Closed: Monday& Public Holidays
Dastaan - e - Shahadat
Virasat E khalsa
